title: How to Cook Dried Beans Quickly

steps.headline: Put the beans, water, oil, salt, and optional seasonings in the cooker.
steps.description: Decide what kind of beans you want to cook and put 1 pound (0.45 kg) of them into a pressure cooker along with 8 cups (1.9 l) of water, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, and 1 to 2 teaspoons (5.5 to 11 g) of salt. If you'd like to flavor the beans as they cook, add 2 to 3 cloves of peeled garlic and 1 bay leaf. Use a 6 to 8 quart (5.6 to 7.5 liter) pressure cooker to ensure that the ingredients don't fill the pressure cooker more than half full.

steps.headline: Close the cooker and pressure cook the beans for 20 to 40 minutes.
steps.description:
Secure the pressure cooker lid so it's sealed shut. Adjust the pressure to high and set the timer based on what type of bean you're cooking. Use these guidelines to determine how long to pressure-cook the beans:
Black beans and black-eyed peas: 20 to 25 minutes
Great Northern, navy, and pinto beans: 25 to 30 minutes
Cannellini and garbanzo beans: 35 to 40 minutes

steps.headline: Release the pressure from the pressure cooker.
steps.description: If you're in a hurry, open the pressure valve at the top of your pressure cooker to do a quick release. Keep in mind that this rapid release of pressure can cause some of the beans to split. For a slower pressure release, let it release naturally. A natural pressure release will take about 20 to 30 minutes before you can open the pressure cooker. If you're doing a quick pressure release, keep your hands and face away from the steam as it escapes.

steps.headline: Open the pressure cooker and use the beans.
steps.description: Once the pressure is released, put a fine mesh strainer in the sink and pour the cooked beans into it. The cooking liquid will drain off and you can now use the beans in your recipes. If you open the cooker to find that the beans aren't cooked enough, secure the lid and pressure cook the beans on high for another 5 to 10 minutes. To store cooked beans, put them in an airtight container and refrigerate them for up to 7 days. For longer storage, freeze them for up to 3 months.

steps.headline: Put the beans into a pot and cover them by 2 in (5 cm) of water.
steps.description: Decide what type of beans you want to cook and put 1 pound (0.45 kg) of dried beans into a large pot. Set the pot on the stove and pour in enough cold water to cover the beans by 2 inches (5.1 cm). Look over the beans and discard any that are broken.

steps.headline: Cover the pot and bring the water to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the burner to high and heat the beans in the water. The water should begin to boil and steam will escape from under the lid. There's no need to stir the beans as the water begins to boil.

steps.headline: Let the beans soak for 1 hour off the heat.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and keep the lid on the pot. The beans should quick soak for 1 hour so they soften a little. You don't have to stir the beans as they're soaking. If you'd rather soak the beans overnight instead of quick-soaking them, put the beans in the pot and cover them with cool water. Let the beans sit at room temperature for at least 8 hours. Then you don't need to do the quick-soaking steps.

steps.headline: Add the salt and bring the beans to a boil.
steps.description: Take the lid off of the pot and stir 1 1/2 teaspoons (9 g) of kosher salt into beans until the salt is dissolved. Turn the burner on to medium and heat the beans until the water boils gently.

steps.headline: Simmer the beans for 1 to 2 hours.
steps.description:
Leave the pot uncovered as the water simmers. Stir the beans occasionally to prevent them from clumping together. They should soften and become tender once they've finished cooking. You may need to adjust the burner if the water boils vigorously. Cook the beans according to these guidelines:
Lima and pink beans: 1 hour
Black, kidney, navy, pinto, or garbanzo beans: 1 to 1 1/2 hours
Field peas: 2 hours

steps.headline: Use the cooked beans in a recipe or save them for later use.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and set a fine mesh strainer in the sink. Carefully pour the cooked beans into the strainer so the water drains. Then you can use the beans or refrigerate them in an airtight container for up to 3 to 5 days. For longer storage, put the beans in an airtight container and freeze them for up to 6 months.

text:
Pressure-Cooked Beans Put the beans, water, oil, salt, and optional seasonings in the cooker. Decide what kind of beans you want to cook and put 1 pound (0.45 kg) of them into a pressure cooker along with 8 cups (1.9 l) of water, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, and 1 to 2 teaspoons (5.5 to 11 g) of salt. If you'd like to flavor the beans as they cook, add 2 to 3 cloves of peeled garlic and 1 bay leaf. Use a 6 to 8 quart (5.6 to 7.5 liter) pressure cooker to ensure that the ingredients don't fill the pressure cooker more than half full. Close the cooker and pressure cook the beans for 20 to 40 minutes. Secure the pressure cooker lid so it's sealed shut. Adjust the pressure to high and set the timer based on what type of bean you're cooking. Use these guidelines to determine how long to pressure-cook the beans:
Black beans and black-eyed peas: 20 to 25 minutes
Great Northern, navy, and pinto beans: 25 to 30 minutes
Cannellini and garbanzo beans: 35 to 40 minutes Release the pressure from the pressure cooker. If you're in a hurry, open the pressure valve at the top of your pressure cooker to do a quick release. Keep in mind that this rapid release of pressure can cause some of the beans to split. For a slower pressure release, let it release naturally. A natural pressure release will take about 20 to 30 minutes before you can open the pressure cooker. If you're doing a quick pressure release, keep your hands and face away from the steam as it escapes. Open the pressure cooker and use the beans. Once the pressure is released, put a fine mesh strainer in the sink and pour the cooked beans into it. The cooking liquid will drain off and you can now use the beans in your recipes. If you open the cooker to find that the beans aren't cooked enough, secure the lid and pressure cook the beans on high for another 5 to 10 minutes. To store cooked beans, put them in an airtight container and refrigerate them for up to 7 days. For longer storage, freeze them for up to 3 months. Quick-Soaked Stove Top Beans Put the beans into a pot and cover them by 2 in (5 cm) of water. Decide what type of beans you want to cook and put 1 pound (0.45 kg) of dried beans into a large pot. Set the pot on the stove and pour in enough cold water to cover the beans by 2 inches (5.1 cm). Look over the beans and discard any that are broken. Cover the pot and bring the water to a boil. Turn the burner to high and heat the beans in the water. The water should begin to boil and steam will escape from under the lid. There's no need to stir the beans as the water begins to boil. Let the beans soak for 1 hour off the heat. Turn off the burner and keep the lid on the pot. The beans should quick soak for 1 hour so they soften a little. You don't have to stir the beans as they're soaking. If you'd rather soak the beans overnight instead of quick-soaking them, put the beans in the pot and cover them with cool water. Let the beans sit at room temperature for at least 8 hours. Then you don't need to do the quick-soaking steps. Add the salt and bring the beans to a boil. Take the lid off of the pot and stir 1 1/2 teaspoons (9 g) of kosher salt into beans until the salt is dissolved. Turn the burner on to medium and heat the beans until the water boils gently. Simmer the beans for 1 to 2 hours. Leave the pot uncovered as the water simmers. Stir the beans occasionally to prevent them from clumping together. They should soften and become tender once they've finished cooking. You may need to adjust the burner if the water boils vigorously. Cook the beans according to these guidelines:
Lima and pink beans: 1 hour
Black, kidney, navy, pinto, or garbanzo beans: 1 to 1 1/2 hours
Field peas: 2 hours Use the cooked beans in a recipe or save them for later use. Turn off the burner and set a fine mesh strainer in the sink. Carefully pour the cooked beans into the strainer so the water drains. Then you can use the beans or refrigerate them in an airtight container for up to 3 to 5 days. For longer storage, put the beans in an airtight container and freeze them for up to 6 months.
